1.verse: The consolation of God in trouble. The love of Paul toward the Corinthians, and his reason for not going to them earlier. Paul, an apostle of Jesus Christ by the will of God, and brother Timothy. To the congregation of God which is at Corinth, with all the saints who are in all Achaia.

2.verse: Grace be with you and peace from God our Father and from the Lord Jesus Christ.

3.verse: Blessed be God the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, the Father of mercy and the God of all comfort,

4.verse: who comforts us in all our tribulation, insomuch that we are able to comfort others who are troubled, in whatsoever tribulation it may be, with the same comfort that we ourselves are comforted with by God.

5.verse: For as the afflictions of Christ are plentiful in us, so also is our consolation plentiful by Christ.

6.verse: Whether we are troubled regarding your consolation and salvation, which salvation shows her power in that you suffer the same afflictions that we also suffer, or whether we are comforted regarding your consolation and salvation,

7.verse: yet our hope is steadfast for you, inasmuch as we know that as you have your part in afflictions, so shall you be partakers of consolation.

8.verse: Brethren, I would not have you unaware of the trouble that happened to us in Asia. For we were grieved out of measure passing strength, so greatly that we despaired even of life.

9.verse: Also, we received an answer of death in ourselves, and that because we should not put our trust in ourselves, but in God, who raises the dead to life again,

10.verse: and who delivered us from so great a death, and does deliver. On whom we trust that yet hereafter he will deliver,

11.verse: by the help of your prayer for us, so that by reason of many deliverances thanks may be given by many for us, for the grace given to us.

12.verse: Our assurance is this: the testimony of our conscience, that in sincerity and godly purity, and not in fleshly wisdom, but by the grace of God we have conducted ourselves in the world, and most of all toward you.

13.verse: We write no other things to you than what you read and also know. Yea and I trust you will find us to the end

14.verse: just as you have found us so far. For we are your delight and joy, even as you are ours in the day of the Lord Jesus.

15.verse: And in this confidence I was minded the other time to have gone to you, so that you might have had yet one pleasure more,

16.verse: and to have passed by you on the way to Macedonia, and to have come again out of Macedonia to you, and to have been led on my way toward Judea by you.

17.verse: When I was so minded, was it lightly? Or do I think carnally the things that I think, such that with me there should be yea, yea, and nay, nay?

18.verse: God is faithful. For our preaching to you was not yea and nay.

19.verse: For God’s Son Jesus Christ, who was preached among you by us (that is to say, by me and Silvanus and Timothy) was not yea and nay, but in him was yea.

20.verse: For all the promises of God in him are yea, and are in him Amen, to the laud of God through us.

21.verse: For it is God who established us and you in Christ, and has anointed us;

22.verse: who has also sealed us, and has given the earnest of the Spirit into our hearts.

23.verse: He explains the reason for his absence. He exhorts them to forgive the man who was fallen, and to receive him again with love. I call God as a witness to my soul that it was to favour you that I did not go any more to Corinth.

24.verse: Not that we are lords over your faith, but are helpers of your joy.

1.verse: For by faith you stand. But I determined in myself that I would not come again to you in heaviness.

2.verse: For if I make you sorrowful, who is it that should make me glad, but the same who are made sorrowful by me?

3.verse: And I wrote this same epistle to you lest, if I went, I should be made sad by those of whom I ought to rejoice. Certainly this confidence I have in you all: that my joy is the joy of you all.

4.verse: For in great affliction and anguish of heart I wrote to you, with many tears – not to make you sorrowful, but so that you might perceive the love that I have most specially for you.

5.verse: But if any man has caused grief, he has not grieved me but in part – lest I should overburden you all.

6.verse: It is enough for the same man that he was rebuked by many. So now, instead, you ought to forgive him, and comfort him,

7.verse: lest that same person should be swallowed up with overmuch heaviness.

8.verse: Therefore I exhort you, so that love may have the power over him.

9.verse: For this reason also I wrote: to know the proof of you, whether you would be obedient in all things.

10.verse: Whomever you forgive for anything, I forgive also. And if I forgive a person anything, I forgive it for your sakes in the place of Christ,

11.verse: lest Satan should get the advantage of us. For his devices are not unknown to us.

12.verse: When I had come to Troas for the sake of Christ’s gospel (and a great door was opened to me by the Lord),

13.verse: I had no rest in my spirit, because I did not find Titus my brother. So I took my leave of them and went away into Macedonia –

14.verse: thanks be to God, who always gives us the victory in Christ, and opens the savour of the knowledge of him by us in every place.

15.verse: For we are for God the sweet savour of Christ, both among those who are saved and also among those who are perishing.

16.verse: To the one part we are the savour of death unto death, and to the other part we are the savour of life unto life. And who is fit for these things?

17.verse: For we are not as many are, who tamper with the word of God. But it is out of pureness, and by the power of God, and in the sight of God, that we speak in Christ.

1.verse: Paul praises the preaching of the gospel above the preaching of the law. We begin to praise ourselves again. Do we like some others need letters of recommendation to you? or letters of recommendation from you?

2.verse: You are our letter written in our hearts, which is understood and read by all people,

3.verse: in that it is known that you are the epistle of Christ through our work – and written not with ink, but with the Spirit of the living God, and not in tablets of stone, but in fleshly tablets of the heart.

4.verse: Such confidence we have through Christ in God.

5.verse: It is not that we are competent in and of ourselves, so as to think a good thought, as it were, by ourselves. But our ability comes from God,

6.verse: who has made us able to minister the new testament – not of the letter, but of the Spirit. For the letter kills, but the Spirit gives life.

7.verse: If the ministration of death through the letters figured in stones was so glorious that the children of Israel could not behold the face of Moses for the glory of his countenance (which glory nevertheless is done away with),

8.verse: why shall not the ministration of the Spirit be much more glorious?

9.verse: For if the ministering of condemnation is glorious, much more does the ministration of righteousness exceed in glory.

10.verse: For without doubt, that which was there glorified is not once glorified in relation to this surpassing glory.

11.verse: So then, if that which is destroyed was glorious, much more will that which remains be glorious.

12.verse: Seeing then that we have such confidence, we speak boldly,

13.verse: and do not do as Moses, who put a veil over his face so that the children of Israel could not see the purpose served by that which is abolished.

14.verse: But their minds were blinded. For until this day, the same covering remains unremoved in the old testament when they read it, which in Christ is put away.

15.verse: But even to this day, when Moses is read, the veil hangs before their hearts.

16.verse: Nevertheless, when they turn to the Lord, the veil shall be taken away.

17.verse: The Lord no doubt is a Spirit. And where the Spirit of the Lord is, there is liberty.

18.verse: And we all behold the glory of the Lord with his face revealed, and are changed into his likeness from glory to glory, even by the Spirit of the Lord.

1.verse: A true preacher is diligent. He does not corrupt the word of God. He does not preach himself, but seeks the honour of Christ – yea though it be at the risk of his life. Therefore seeing that we have such an office, even as mercy has come on us, we faint not,

2.verse: but have cast from us the cloaks of dishonesty, and do not walk in craftiness. Neither do we corrupt the word of God, but walk in open truth, and appeal to every man’s conscience in the sight of God.

3.verse: If our gospel be yet hid, it is hid among those who are lost,

4.verse: in whom the god of this world has blinded the minds of those who do not believe, lest the light of the glorious gospel of Christ, who is the image of God, should shine unto them.

5.verse: For we preach not ourselves, but Christ Jesus to be the Lord, and ourselves your servants for Jesus’ sake.

6.verse: For it is God who commanded the light to shine out of darkness, which has shone in our hearts to give the light of the knowledge of the glory of God in the face of Jesus Christ.

7.verse: But we have this treasure in earthen vessels so that the surpassing power of it may be seen to be of God, and not of us.

8.verse: We are troubled on every side, yet we are not without means. We are in poverty, but not utterly bereft.

9.verse: We are persecuted, but are not forsaken. We are cast down, nevertheless we do not perish.

10.verse: And we always bear in our bodies the dying of the Lord Jesus so that the life of Jesus may appear in our bodies.

11.verse: For we who live are always delivered to death for Jesus’ sake, so that the life also of Jesus may appear in our mortal flesh.

12.verse: So then, death works in us, and life in you.

13.verse: Seeing then that we have the same spirit of faith as is written of – I believed, and therefore I have spoken – we also believe, and therefore speak.

14.verse: For we know that he who raised up the Lord Jesus will raise us up also by the means of Jesus, and will set us with you.

15.verse: For I do all things for your sakes, so that the abundant grace, through thanks given by many, may redound to the glory of God.

16.verse: And so we are not wearied, but though our outward man perish, yet the inward man is renewed day by day.

17.verse: For our exceeding tribulation, which is momentary and light, prepares an exceeding and an eternal weight of glory for us,

18.verse: while we look not on the things that are seen, but on the things which are not seen. For the things that are seen are temporal, but the things which are not seen, are eternal.

1.verse: The reward for suffering trouble. We know surely that if our earthly abode, the tabernacle we now dwell in, were destroyed, we have an abode prepared by God: a habitation not made with hands, but eternal in heaven.

2.verse: And for this we sigh, desiring to be clothed with our dwelling which is from heaven –

3.verse: if yet we be found clothed, and not naked.

4.verse: For as long as we are in this tabernacle, we sigh and are grieved. For we would not be unclothed, but would be clothed upon, so that mortality may be swallowed up by life.

5.verse: He who has ordained us for this thing is God, the very same who has given to us the earnest of the Spirit.

6.verse: Therefore we are always of good cheer. And we know well that as long as we are at home in the body, we are away from God.

7.verse: For we walk in faith, and see not.

8.verse: Nevertheless, we are of good comfort – and yet would rather be away from the body, and be present with the Lord.

9.verse: And so whether we are at home or away from home, we endeavour to please him.

10.verse: For we must all appear before the judgment seat of Christ, so that every person may receive the works of his body, according to what he has done, whether it be good or bad.

11.verse: Seeing then that we know how the Lord is to be feared, we fare fair with men. For we are known well enough to God. I trust also that we are known in your consciences.

12.verse: We are not praising ourselves again to you, but give you reason to have confidence in us, so that you may have something to answer to those who put confidence in the face, and not in the heart.

13.verse: For if we are too fervent, it is for God that we are too fervent. If we are restrained, it is for your sakes that we show restraint.

14.verse: For the love of Christ constrains us, because we judge this way: if one is dead for all, then all are dead;

15.verse: and that he died for all so that those who live should henceforth live not for themselves, but for him who died for them and rose again.

16.verse: And so henceforth we know no man after the flesh, insomuch that even if we have known Christ after the flesh, now henceforth we know him this way no more.

17.verse: Therefore if any person is in Christ, he is a new creature. Old things have passed away: behold, all things are become new.

18.verse: Nevertheless, all things are of God, who has reconciled us to himself by Jesus Christ, and has given to us the office to preach the atonement.

19.verse: For God was in Christ, and made agreement between the world and himself, and did not impute people’s sins to them. And he has committed to us the preaching of the atonement.

20.verse: Now then, we are messengers in the place of Christ, even as though God did beseech you through us. So we entreat you in Christ’s stead to be at one with God.

21.verse: For he has made him who knew no sin to be a sin offering for us, so that we, by means of him, should be that righteousness which is accepted before God.

1.verse: An exhortation to receive the word of God with thankfulness and amendment of life. The diligence of Paul in the gospel, and how he warns them to avoid the company of the heathen. We as helpers therefore exhort you, do not receive the grace of God in vain.

2.verse: For he says: I have heard you in a favoured time, and in the day of salvation I have succoured you. Behold, now is that well-favoured time; behold, now is that day of salvation.

3.verse: Let us give no one occasion for evil, so that in our service no fault may be found,

4.verse: but in all things let us behave ourselves as the ministers of God in much patience – in afflictions, in hardship, in anguish,

5.verse: in stripes, in prison, in strife, in labour, in sleeplessness, in hunger;

6.verse: in pureness, in knowledge, in longsuffering, in kindness, in the Holy Spirit, in love unfeigned,

7.verse: in the words of truth; in the power of God, with the armour of righteousness on the right hand and on the left;

8.verse: in honour and dishonour, in evil report and good report, as deceivers and yet true,

9.verse: as unknown and yet known. As dying, and behold, we live yet; as chastened, and not killed;

10.verse: as sorrowing, and yet always merry; as poor, and yet making many rich; as having nothing, and yet possessing all things.

11.verse: O ye Corinthians, we pursue you with many words. Our hearts yearn to you.

12.verse: You are not shut out in us, but are shut away in your own selves.

13.verse: I promise you like reward with me, as to my children. So set yourselves free,

14.verse: and bear not a stranger’s yoke with the unbelievers. For what fellowship has righteousness with unrighteousness? What communion has light with darkness?

15.verse: What concord has Christ with Belial? Or what part has he who believes with an infidel?

16.verse: How does the temple of God agree with idols? And you are the temple of the living God, as God said: I will dwell among them and walk among them, and will be their God, and they shall be my people.

17.verse: Therefore: Come out from among them, and separate yourselves (says the Lord), and touch no unclean thing, and I will receive you,

18.verse: and will be a father to you, and you will be my sons and daughters, says the Lord Almighty.

1.verse: He exhorts them to receive the promises of God thankfully. The Corinthians are commended for their obedience and love toward Paul. Seeing that we have such promises, dearly beloveds, let us cleanse ourselves from all defilement of the flesh and spirit, and grow up to full holiness in the fear of God.

2.verse: Understand us: we have hurt no one, we have corrupted no one, we have defrauded no one.

3.verse: I do not say this to condemn you, for I have told you before that you are in our hearts, to die and live with you.

4.verse: I make very much of you, and rejoice greatly in you. I am filled with comfort and am exceedingly joyous in all our tribulations.

5.verse: For when we had come into Macedonia, we had no rest in our flesh, but we were troubled on every side. Outwardly was conflict, inwardly was fear.

6.verse: Nevertheless, God, who comforts the abject, comforted us at the coming of Titus.

7.verse: And not with his coming only, but also with the consolation that he was comforted with by you. For he told us of your longing, your mourning, your fervent heart for me, so that I now rejoice the more.

8.verse: Therefore, though I made you sorrowful with a letter, I do not regret it – though I did have regrets. For I realize that the letter made you sorrowful, though it was but for a season.

9.verse: But now I am happy – not that you were sorrowful, but that you so sorrowed that you repented. For your sorrow was godly, so that in nothing were you hurt by us.

10.verse: For godly sorrow causes repentance unto salvation, not to be regretted, while worldly sorrow causes death.

11.verse: Behold what diligence this godly sorrow that you felt has wrought in you. Yea, it caused you to clear yourselves: it led to indignation, it led to fear, it led to desire, it led to a fervent mind, it led to punishment. For in every point you have shown yourselves to be clear in that matter.

12.verse: So although I wrote to you, I did it not for the sake of him who did the injury, nor for the sake of him who was injured, but so that our good mind that we have toward you in the sight of God might appear to you.

13.verse: Therefore we are comforted because you are comforted. Yea and we rejoiced much more for the joy that Titus had, because his spirit was refreshed by you all.

14.verse: I am therefore not now ashamed, though I boasted to him of you. For just as all the things that I preached to you are true, so also the boasts that I made to Titus are found true.

15.verse: And now his inward affection for you is greater when he remembers the obedience of every one of you, how with fear and trembling you received him.

16.verse: I rejoice that I may be reassured about you in every point.

1.verse: He reminds them to help the poor saints in Jerusalem, as the Macedonians did. He sends Titus ahead. I want you to understand, brethren, of the grace of God that is given in the congregations of Macedonia,

2.verse: how the greatness of their joy is in that they are tried with much tribulation. And moreover, though they were very poor, yet they have given very liberally, and that in sincerity.

3.verse: For as they were able (I am witness), yea and beyond their ability, they were willing of their own accord,

4.verse: and insisted that we take their gift and let them be partakers with others in ministering to the saints.

5.verse: And this they did not as we looked for, but gave their own selves first to the Lord, and after to us by the will of God.

6.verse: So we could not but desire Titus to accomplish the same work of grace among you too, even as he had begun.

7.verse: Now therefore, as you are rich in all respects – in faith, in word, in knowledge, in all ferventness, and in love, which you have to us – so also see to it that you contribute generously to this gift.

8.verse: I say this, not as commanding, but, seeing others are so fervent, to prove your love also, whether it be perfect or no.

9.verse: You know the munificence of our Lord Jesus Christ, who, though he was rich, yet for your sakes became poor, so that you through his poverty could be made rich.

10.verse: And I give counsel in the matter because to do this is proper for you, who began not only to do, but also to will, a year ago.

11.verse: Now therefore perform the deed, so that as there was in you a ready willingness, so also you follow through, out of what you have.

12.verse: For if there is first a willing mind, it is accepted according to what a person has, and not according to what he does not have.

13.verse: It is not my mind that others be set at ease and you be burdened,

14.verse: but, so that there be equality now at this time, that your abundance may relieve their lack, and that their abundance also hereafter may supply your lack – so that there may be equality,

15.verse: agreeing to that which is written: He who gathered much had nothing over, and he who gathered little had no lack.

16.verse: Thanks be to God, who put in the heart of Titus the same good mind toward you.

17.verse: For he accepted the request; yea rather, he was so well willing, that of his own accord he has gone to you.

18.verse: And we have sent with him that brother whose renown is in the gospel throughout all the congregations.

19.verse: And not only this, he has also been chosen by the congregations to be a fellow traveler with us in our journey concerning this gift, which is ministered by us for the praise of the Lord, and to stir up your ready mind.

20.verse: For we want to guard against anyone finding fault with us in this large distribution that we are attending to,

21.verse: and therefore provide for things to be beyond reproach, not only in the sight of God, but also in the sight of men.

22.verse: And we have sent with them a brother of ours whom we have often found eager to help in many things, but now much more eager. The great confidence that I have in you has caused me to do this –

23.verse: partly for the sake of Titus, who is my fellow and helper concerning you all, and partly because of others who are our brethren, and the messengers of the congregations, and the glory of Christ.

24.verse: Therefore show them the proof of your love, and of our boasting about you, so that the congregations may see it.

1.verse: In this chapter he does the same that he did in the chapter going before; that is, moves them to help the poor brethren in Jerusalem. Of the ministering to the saints, it is more than I need do to write to you.

2.verse: For I know your readiness of mind, of which I boast to the Macedonians, and say that Achaia was prepared a year ago, and your ferventness has inspired many.

3.verse: Nevertheless, I have sent these brethren lest our boasting over you should be in vain in this respect, and so that you (as I have said) will prepare yourselves –

4.verse: lest perhaps, if some of the Macedonians come with me and find you unprepared, the boast I made in this matter should be an embarrassment to us, not to mention to you.

5.verse: Therefore I thought it necessary to exhort the brethren to go beforehand to you, to arrange for the good blessing you promised earlier, so it could be ready – so that it is a blessing, and not a defrauding.

6.verse: Remember this: he who sows little will reap little, and he who sows plentifully will reap plentifully.

7.verse: And let every person do as he has purposed in his heart – not grudgingly, or under constraint. For God loves a cheerful giver.

8.verse: God is able to make you rich in all grace, so that you, in all things having sufficient to the utmost, may be rich for all manner of good works.

9.verse: As it is written: He who dispersed abroad and has given to the poor, his righteousness remains forever.

10.verse: He who gives the sower seed will provide bread for food, and will multiply your seed, and increase the fruits of your righteousness,

11.verse: so that in everything you may be made rich, in all generosity – which raises through us thanksgiving to God.

12.verse: For the work of this ministry not only supplies the need of the saints, but is also fruitful in that for this laudable ministering, thanks may be given to God by many,

13.verse: who glorify God for the obedience of your profession of the gospel of Christ, and for your generosity in distributing to them and to all people.

14.verse: And in their prayers to God for you they long after you, for the abundant grace of God given to you.

15.verse: Thanks be to God for his indescribable gift.

1.verse: He refers to the false apostles, and defends his authority and calling. I Paul myself beseech you, by the meekness and softness of Christ – I who when I am present among you am of no reputation, but am bold toward you when absent.

2.verse: I beseech you so that I need not to be bold when I am present (with that same confidence that I am supposed to be bold with) toward some who consider us as though we walked carnally.

3.verse: Nevertheless, though we walk encompassed with the flesh, we do not war after the flesh.

4.verse: For the weapons of our warfare are not carnal things, but things mighty in God to cast down strongholds,

5.verse: with which we overthrow imaginations and every high thing that exalts itself against the knowledge of God, and bring into captivity all understanding to the obedience of Christ,

6.verse: and are ready to take vengeance on all disobedience, when your obedience might come to an end.

7.verse: Do you look on things after the outward appearance? If anyone trusts in himself that he is Christ’s, let him also consider that as he is Christ’s, so also are we Christ’s.

8.verse: And if I were to boast somewhat of our authority, which the Lord has given us to build up, and not to break you down, it would not be to my discredit.

9.verse: I say this so that I do not seem as though I went about to make you afraid with letters.

10.verse: For the epistles (says he) are strong, but his bodily presence is weak, and his speech is poor.

11.verse: Let such a man think of it this way: that as we are in words by letters when we are absent, such are we in deeds when we are present.

12.verse: For we cannot find in our hearts to make ourselves of their number, or to compare ourselves with those who laud themselves, nevertheless while they measure themselves against themselves, and compare themselves with themselves, they understand nothing.

13.verse: But we will not boast unduly, but according to the measure of the work that God has assigned to us – a work that reaches even to you.

14.verse: For we are not overrating ourselves, as if we had not reached to you, because we did reach you with the gospel of Christ.

15.verse: And we do not claim undue credit for other men’s labours. Yea and we hope, when your faith is increased among you, to be advanced further in our work,

16.verse: and to preach the gospel in those regions that are beyond you – and not to boast of that which is prepared already by another man’s work.

17.verse: But let him who boasts, boast in the Lord.

18.verse: For he who praises himself is not accepted, but he whom the Lord praises.

1.verse: Paul (with reluctance) commends himself, and defends his authority against the false prophets. I would you could suffer me a little in my foolishness, yea and I ask you to bear with me.

2.verse: For I am jealous over you with godly jealousy. For I espoused you to one man, to present you a chaste virgin to Christ.

3.verse: But I fear that, as the serpent beguiled Eve through his subtlety, so your minds might be corrupted from the simplicity that is in Christ.

4.verse: For if he who comes preaches another Jesus than him whom we preached, or if you are given another spirit than that which you were given, or another gospel than that which you were given, you might right well be content.

5.verse: I suppose that I was not behind the chief apostles.

6.verse: Though I be poor in speaking, yet I am not so in knowledge. However, among you we are known to the utmost, who we are in all things.

7.verse: Did I sin, because I humbled myself so that you could be exalted, and because I preached to you the gospel of God free?

8.verse: I robbed other congregations, and took support from them in order to serve you.

9.verse: And when I was present with you and had need, I was a burden to no one, for that which was lacking to me, the brethren who came from Macedonia supplied. And in all things I kept myself so that I would not be burdensome to you. And I will continue so to keep myself.

10.verse: If the truth of Christ is in me, this claim will not be taken from me in the regions of Achaia.

11.verse: Why? Because I do not love you? God knows.

12.verse: Nevertheless, what I do, that I will continue to do, so as to cut away occasion from those who desire occasion to seem like us in the things that they claim.

13.verse: For the false apostles are deceitful workers, and fashion themselves to be like the apostles of Christ.

14.verse: And no wonder, for Satan himself is changed into the fashion of an angel of light.

15.verse: Therefore it is no great thing if his ministers fashion themselves as though they were the ministers of righteousness – whose end shall be according to their deeds.

16.verse: I say again, lest anyone think that I am foolish, or else even now take me as a fool if I boast a little,

17.verse: that what I am saying I do not say after the ways of the Lord, but as it were foolishly, since we have now come to boasting.

18.verse: Seeing that many boast after the flesh, I will boast also.

19.verse: For you suffer fools gladly, because you yourselves are wise.

20.verse: For you oblige even if a man brings you into bondage, if a man devours, if a man takes, if a man exalts himself, if a man strikes you on the face.

21.verse: I speak by way of rebuke. As if we were weak! However, in any point a man dares to presume (I speak foolishly), I dare to presume also:

22.verse: they are Hebrews; so am I. They are Israelites; so am I. They are the seed of Abraham; so am I.

23.verse: They are the ministers of Christ (I speak like a fool); I am more so: in labours more abundant, in stripes above measure, in prison more frequently, in death often.

24.verse: Five times from the Jews I received every time forty stripes less one.

25.verse: Three times I was beaten with rods. I was once stoned. I suffered shipwreck three times. Night and day I have been in the deep of the sea,

26.verse: often journeying, in danger in rivers, in danger from robbers, in danger from my own nation, in danger among the heathen. I have been in danger in cities, in danger in the countryside, in danger on the sea, in danger among false brethren,

27.verse: in labour and travail, in sleepless nights often, in hunger, in thirst – going without food often, in cold and without clothing.

28.verse: And besides the things that outwardly happen to me, I am daily concerned and do care for all the congregations.

29.verse: Who is sick, and I am not sick? Who is hurt in the faith and my heart does not burn?

30.verse: If I must boast, I will boast of my afflictions.

31.verse: The God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, who is blessed forevermore, knows that I do not speak untruly.

32.verse: In the city of Damascus, the governor of the people under king Aretas laid watch in the city of the Damascenes, and would have captured me.

33.verse: But at a window I was let down in a basket through the wall, and so escaped his hands.

1.verse: Paul is taken up into the third heaven and hears words not to be spoken of. No doubt it is not seemly for me to boast. Nevertheless, I will come to visions and revelations from the Lord.

2.verse: I know a man in Christ about fourteen years ago (whether he was in the body I cannot tell, or whether he was out of the body I cannot tell, God knows) who was taken up into the third heaven.

3.verse: And I know the same man (whether in the body or out of the body I cannot tell, God knows),

4.verse: how he was taken up into Paradise and heard words not to be spoken, which no man can utter.

5.verse: Of this man I will boast. Of myself I will not boast, unless it be of my infirmities.

6.verse: And yet if I chose to boast, I would not be a fool, because I would be speaking the truth. Nevertheless, I refrain, lest anyone should think of me above what he sees me to be, or hears from me.

7.verse: And lest I should be unduly lifted up through the greatness of the revelations, there was given to me unquietness of the flesh, the messenger of Satan to buffet me – because I should not be unduly lifted up.

8.verse: For this thing I besought the Lord three times, to put it from me.

9.verse: And he said to me, My grace is sufficient for you, for my strength is made perfect through weakness. Very gladly therefore will I rest in my weakness, so that the strength of Christ may dwell in me.

10.verse: Therefore I am content in infirmities, in reproach, in need, in persecutions, in anguish, for Christ’s sake. For when I am weak, then I am strong.

11.verse: I am made a fool in going on about myself. You have compelled me. I ought to have been commended by you. For in nothing was I inferior to the chief apostles. Though I am nothing,

12.verse: yet the signs that mark an apostle were wrought among you with all patience – with miracles, and wonders, and works of power.

13.verse: For in what were you less favoured than other congregations? – unless it is in that I was not burdensome to you. Forgive me this wrong done to you!

14.verse: And now the third time I am ready to come to you, and still I will not be a burden to you. For I seek not yours, but you. Also, the children ought not to lay up for the fathers and mothers, but the fathers and mothers for the children.

15.verse: I will very gladly give, and will be given, for your souls – though the more I love you, the less I am loved in return.

16.verse: But granted that I did not impose upon you, nevertheless I was crafty and took you with guile –

17.verse: Did I rob you through any of the men that I sent to you?

18.verse: I asked Titus, and with him I sent a brother. Did Titus defraud you of anything? Did we not walk in the same spirit? Did we not walk in like steps?

19.verse: Again, do you think that we are justifying ourselves to you? We speak in Christ, in the sight of God. But we do all things, dearly beloveds, for your upbuilding.

20.verse: For I fear lest it come to pass that when I come, I will not find you such as I would like, and you will find me such as I would not want. I fear lest there be found among you debate, envying, anger, rivalry, backbiting, whisperings, swelling, and discord.

21.verse: I fear that when I come again, God may bring me low among you, and I may be constrained to bewail many of those who have sinned already and have not repented of the uncleanness, fornication, and wantonness that they have committed.

1.verse: He promises to come to them, and he exhorts them to get themselves in order so that he may find them perfect and in harmony. Now I am coming the third time to you. In the mouth of two or three witnesses shall everything be established.

2.verse: I told you before, and I am warning you now, and as I said when I was present with you the second time, so I write now, being absent, to those who in time past have sinned, and to all others: if I come again, I will not spare,

3.verse: seeing that you seek proof of Christ who speaks in me – who among you is not weak, but is mighty in you.

4.verse: And indeed, though it came of weakness that he was crucified, yet he lives through the power of God. And we no doubt are weak in him, but we shall live with him by the might of God among you.

5.verse: Prove yourselves, whether you are in the faith or not. Examine your own selves. Do you not know your own selves that Jesus Christ is in you? – unless you are castaways.

6.verse: I trust that you will realize that we are not castaways.

7.verse: I desire before God that you do no evil – not that we should seem commendable, but that you should do that which is honourable. And let us be counted as uncommendable persons.

8.verse: We can do nothing against the truth, only for the truth.

9.verse: We are glad when we are weak and you strong. This also we wish for: even that you were perfect.

10.verse: Therefore I write these things being absent, lest when I am present I must use sharpness, according to the power that the Lord has given me – to build up, and not to break down.

11.verse: Finally, brethren, fare ye well. Be perfect, be of good comfort, be of one mind, live in peace, and the God of love and peace will be with you.

12.verse: Greet one another in a holy kiss.

13.verse: All the saints send greetings to you.

14.verse: May the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ and the love of God and the fellowship of the Holy Spirit be with you all. Amen. The end of the second epistle to the Corinthians.Sent from Philippi, a city inMacedonia, by thehands of Titusand Lucas.
